text: A cluster of miners wait tensely around the hoist as the cage rises to ground level. Several miners wearing tin ha are crowded inside the cage, but their faces are so grimy we cannot make out who they are.

who have stopped on a little knoll at some distance from the mine head. They are looking down at: THE MINE HEAD, FROM THEIR ANGLE. So many men gather around the injured man or men that we can still not distinguish them. But we see a body placed on a stretcher. Two men carry it toward the waiting ambulance. BACK TO WOMEN. CLOSE GROUP SHOT. One woman breaks away and plunges down the hill. The othe heave a collective sigh -- a sigh of relief, anguish, compassion.

It's Mr. Kalinsky. REAR OF AMBULANCE. MEDIUM SHOT. A large number of miners are milling about. The injured m is lifted into the ambulance and the doors are shut. Just then Mrs. Kalinsky runs up. She pounds on the doors.
(hysterically)
Let me see him! Let me see him! Several miners try to calm her. They lead her away as the ambulance starts up.
Now Mrs. Kalinsky, he's gonna be all right ... His leg's broken, that's all ... Come on now, you can see him in the hospital ...
as Superintendent Alexander comes up to the chief foreman Ramуn is close by. He is dirty, sweating, furious.
How did it happen?
He wandered into a drift -- when this fellow was blasting. He indicates Ramуn.
(seething)
I told you it would happen. It's bound to happen when a man works alone!
(to Ramуn)
Why didn't you give a warning signal?
(indicates Barton, bitterly)
Your foreman says that's a foreman's job.
I checked the drift just before he blasted. It was all clear ... The man must have been asleep or something.
You weren't even there. You were back at the station. Kalinsky told me ...
(softly)
You're a liar, Pancho. A no-good, dirty ... Ramуn lunges at him. Barton fends him off. Ramуn keeps boring in, but Sal Ruiz and Frank Barnes grab him. We hea an angry bedlam.
(in Spanish and English)
Dйjame! I'll kill him! Hold him! Hold him! ... Basta, Ramуn! All right, all right. Break it up ...
(pointing at Ramуn)

You, there. Get a hold on yourself. A man's been hurt. I'm as sorry about it as you are. Savvy? Ramуn finally quiets down. By now the miners have formed ragged phalanx in b.g. The three union negotiators, Ramуn the Superintendent and the Chief Foreman form a group in f.g. Alexander speaks to all of them.
Accidents are costly to everyone -- and to the company most of all. (glances at his watch)
And now, I see no reason to treat the occasion like a paid holiday. Suppose we all get back to work. He takes a couple of steps, stops, noting that no one has moved.
(an order)
Mr. Barton.
(a bluff approach)
All right, fellows, the excitement's over. Let's get to it. Barton starts toward the mine head. But the men do not move. Faintly we hear mutterings in Spanish from the miners' ranks.
...'hora. ... Sн, yo creo que sн. ANOTHER ANGLE, FEATURING ALEXANDER.
(exasperated, to Vidal)
What are they saying?
No savvy.
(turning to Frank)
Well, Barnes? How about it? Tell them to get back to work.
(grinning)
They don't work for me. I work for them.
(sharply)
Ruiz? WIDER ANGLE SHOOTING TOWARD MINERS. Sal Ruiz takes his time. He lights a cigarette. Then he calls out in Spanish:

It's up to you, brothers. A murmur runs through the ranks, "si, si." Several miners glance at Ramуn. Suddenly Ramуn wheels, strides toward th power house, which is adjacent to the head frame of the mine. Passing through the miner's ranks, he bellows at th top of his lungs:
Cente! EXT., POWER HOUSE. CLOSE SHOT, AT DOOR. As the man named Cente (Vicente) sticks his head out the doorway of a galvanized tin shack, we hear a yell from of scene.
Apбgalo! Cente's head disappears.

containing several big industrial circuit breakers. Cente hand comes up, pulls the switch. EXT., HEAD FRAME, FEATURING CRUSHER. The gigantic primary crusher, with rock rattling around i it, suddenly stops.

carrying small lumps of ore from the crusher. The belt stops. BACK TO MEN. FULL SHOT. The stillness is vast and sudden. Ramуn walks back to the massed ranks of his fellow miners. He halts beside Antoni at the end of the file. No one else moves or speaks. CLOSER ANGLE: THE MINERS' RANKS. Antonio nudges Ramуn, indicating, something o.s. Ramуn's head turns, looking off scene. One by one, the heads of t other miners turn, glancing o.s.
standing before the silent miners. Barton realizes that the men are not looking at him, but at something above an beyond him. Barton looks over his shoulder. Alexander slowly follows suit.

standing on the knoll above the mine. They are silent and grave. The women's skirts billow in the wind, like unfurl flags, like the tattered banners of a guerrilla band that has come to offer its services to the regular army.
It is a New Mexico plate, and though it is night we can make out clearly the words on the white background on the plate:

head_text.subj: CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY TO DISCLOSE

text: Cowboy boot perched on a car bumper.

a khaki-clad leg, a pearl-handled revolver in a holster - then the full figure of a deputy leaning on the fender of his car. He is picking his teeth with a matchstick and gazing at: EXT., UNION HALL, SHOOTING PAST SHERIFF'S CAR, NIGHT. The car is parked provocatively near the entrance to the building. A sign over the doorway, lighted by reflectors, identifies the place as the union hall. From within we he the muted tumult of a packed house. In near f.g. is anoth parked car containing several women and children.

That night the men held a union meeting ... just to make the walk-out official. Suddenly we hear a roar of applause from inside the hall. The door opens; Luнs and a tow-headed youngster come bounding out, run toward the car, CAMERA PANNING with the

It didn't take them long. They voted to strike -- 93 to 5. We see the car door open: Ruth Barnes and Teresa emerge from the front seat; Consuelo, holding a sleeping infant, gets out of the back. Esperanza is the last to appear. Estella is asleep in her arms.

... And Teresa said now was the time for us to go in. I didn't want to ... I had never been to a union meeting. But the others said, one go, all go ... We see the women coaxing Esperanza. She follows them reluctantly toward the union hall.

as seen from the entrance. A hundred miners are packed densely on the center block of benches, facing the union officers in b.g. Sal Ruiz is presiding; Frank Barnes sits at the table beside him. Charley Vidal stands near the chairman, delivering an impassioned speech.
We have many complaints, brothers, and many demands. But they all add up to one word: Equality! Over sound track we hear the Spanish of Charley's speech, but it is modulated to:

The meeting was nearly over when we came in. Charley Vidal was making a speech. He said there was only one issue in this strike -- equality. But the mine owners would stop at nothing to keep them from getting equality. THE HALL. ANOTHER ANGLE, INCLUDING THE WOMEN. The men are so intent on Charley Vidal's speech that they do not notice the entrance of the women, who tip-toe unobtrusively to the side of the room where they take sea on the unoccupied wall bench. Estella wakes up, blinking the bright lights. THE HALL. FULL SHOT, FEATURING CHARLEY.

He said the bosses would try to split the Anglo and Mexican-American workers and offer rewards to one man if he would sell out his brother... There was only one answer to that, Charley said -- solidarity. The solidarity of working men. Charley concludes his speech.

To all this, brothers, there is only one answer, the solidarity of working men! He sits down to loud applause which comes up over sound track. Sal Ruiz rises, bangs his gavel. GROUP SHOT: THE WOMEN. Ruth and Teresa nudge Consuelo, trying to get her to rise -- but Consuelo, frightened, clings to her sleeping infan Ruth grabs the baby and Teresa practically pushes Consuel to her feet. WIDER ANGLE, SHOOTING PAST SAL, INCLUDING WOMEN. Charley Vidal plucks at Sal's sleeve, points in the direction of the women.
Yes? You ladies have an announcement?
(haltingly)
Well -- it's not an announcement, I guess. The ladies wanted me to ...
Louder!
Consuelo, will you speak from over here? Painfully self-conscious, Consuelo moves toward camera in f.g. She faces the men and begins again, nervous, but trying to speak louder.

The ladies have been talking about sanitation ... and we were thinking ... if the issue is equality, like you say it is, then maybe we ought to have equality in plumbing too ... CLOSE GROUP SHOT: MINERS. Some appear resentful of the women's intrusion; others se amused. Antonio whispers something to Alfredo. Alfredo laughs. Frowning, Ramуn looks around at Esperanza, as he might look at a woman who entered church uncovered.

I mean, maybe it could be a strike demand ... and some of the ladies thought -- it might be a good idea to have a ladies auxiliary! Well, we would like to help out .. . if we can ... FULL SHOT: THE HALL, FEATURING CONSUELO. We hear mild, scattered applause, and then a male falsett giggle sets off a wave of laughter. Ruiz rises, grins sheepishly. Consuelo hurries back to her seat. CAMERA HOL
I'm sure I can speak for all of the brothers. We appreciate the ladies offering to help, but it's getting late and I suggest we table it. The chair will entertain a motion to adjourn.
(from the floor)
Move to adjourn!
Second!

So ordered. He brings down his gavel, and the meeting ends. Some of t miners break for the door, others begin to mill about. Ruth and Consuelo walk to the front of the hall. Now, in quick succession we see four vignettes: TWO SHOT: SAL AND CONSUELO. He meets her near the speaker's table, flings out his arm in a helpless gesture.
Why didn't you check with me? It's embarrassing! TWO SHOT: RUTH AND FRANK. She leans across the speaker's table before Frank can ris and remarks acidly:
Why didn't you support her? You're the worst of the lot.
But honey ...
Or why don't you just put a sign outside? "No dogs or women allowed!" ANOTHER PART OF THE HALL. CHARLEY AND TERESA.
But, Teresa, you can't push these things too fast.
(fiercely)

You were pushing all right -- pushing us right back in our place. ESPERANZA AND RAMУN, NEAR DOORWAY. Esperanza is holding Estella, who is asleep again. Ramуn at the rear of a group of miners filing out of the hall. two of the miners pass Camera, we hear one say to the oth

That's a pretty good idea -- making sanitation one of the demands again. As Ramуn moves into f.g., he indicates with the slightest of gestures for Esperanza to follow. She obeys. EXT., UNION HALL. MEDIUM PANNING SHOT, NIGHT. Ramуn emerges from the hall, moves to a corner of the building in f.g. Esperanza joins him there in the darknes Ramуn speaks softly.
At least you didn't make a fool of yourself -- like Consuelo.

This panorama should be as inclusive as the location site permits. Thirty or more miners march counter-clockwise on a dirt road. Beyond this elliptical picket line on either side of the road are two signs: DELAWARE ZINC CO., INC. KEEP OUT

Though the area is unfenced, these signs mark an imaginar boundary. But access to the mine is difficult except by w of the road. To the right of the road is a steep wooded hillside. The road skirts this hill till it reaches the mountain of waste in deep b.g., then winds uphill to the knoll on which the mine stands. To the left of the road i a railroad spur and a gully. The gully is bridged by trestles, beyond which a fork of the road leads to Zinc Town. Two sheriff's cars are parked on the road near the picket post. No women are visible in this scene.
And so it began -- much like any other strike. There would be no settlement, the company said, till the men returned to their jobs. But their back-to-work movement didn't work.

Two open touring cars loaded with strike-breakers slowly approach the picket line. The lead car stops before this human wall. The pickets make no menacing gestures, but they are ominous in massed silence.
And so the company recruited a few strike-breakers from out of town. We see the lead car make a U-turn and withdraw the way it came. It is followed by the second car.
But they usually lost their nerve when they saw the size of the picket line.

parked near the picket line. A half-dozen deputies stand around idly. They are khaki-clad, booted, wearing their Stetsons with the brims rolled up. They display their side-arms ostentatiously, their holsters hanging low in t fashion of storybook gunmen.
The Sheriff's men were always there. They stood around, showing off their weapons. But the men only marched, day after day, week after week ...
Charley Vidal and another miner stand in the back of a pick-up, distributing rations to Esperanza and Luz Morale The small sacks contain beans, corn meal, coffee, etc.

At first it was a kind of unwritten rule that the women stay at home. The union gave us rations and we had to figure out how to feed our families on them ... EXT., PICKET LINE. MEDIUM SHOT, DAY. There are fewer pickets now, and the miners, weary of the monotony, march in a more leisurely fashion. We see Mrs. Salazar (the old lady introduced at the maсanita) standin close by the picket line. She is crocheting. Ramуn, the picket captain, and other miners glance uncomfortably at her.
But then one morning Mrs. Salazar went to the picket line. Her husband had been killed in a strike many years before ... and she wanted to be there.
Mrs. Salazar is now marching with the men. She is still crocheting. Her expression of calm determination is unchanging.
Nobody remembers just how it happened, but one day Mrs. Salazar started marching with them ... and she kept on marching with them.
We see Teresa Vidal standing beside an old jalopy, pourin a cup of coffee for her husband.
After a while some of the women began to bring coffee for their husbands ... and maybe a couple of tacos -- because a man gets tired and hungry on picket duty ...
Several pickets gape ravenously at Antonio as he bites in the tacos given him by Luz.
It was about that time the union decided maybe they'd better set up a Ladies Auxiliary after all.

and another day. A number of miners have turned carpenter erecting a shack of scrap lumber and galvanized tin close by the picket line. Several women have set up a table outside the unfinished shack on which we see a pot of beans, a coffee pot, etc. Esperanza is not among them.
The shack is now complete. We see Ramуn approach the doorway, where a woman hands him a cup of coffee. He tast it, makes a wry face.
I didn't come to the lines at first. My time was near -- and besides, Ramуn didn't approve. But Ramуn is a man who loves good coffee. And he swore the other ladies made it taste like zinc sludge ...

Standing in the doorway, her pregnancy is more evident th ever. But her face is alight with one of her rare smiles she pours a cup of coffee and hands it to Ramуn. Estella can be seen peeking out from behind her mother's skirt.

So one day I made the coffee ... CAMERA PANS with Ramуn as he strolls back toward the pick line, sipping his coffee. GROUP SHOTS AT PICKET LINE. The men are not marching now, but standing in groups on t road. Kalinsky is among them, on crutches, his leg in a cast. Ramуn takes a sheet of paper from his shirt pocket and checks it.
Now let's see ... who's missing? Prieto, Sebastian. Prieto?
Haven't seen him for two days.
(entering scene, grinning)

Hey, Ramуn -- listen to this. The chief foreman come to me last night, said he'd make me shift foreman if I'd start a back-to-work movement. "Jenkins," he says, "why string along with them tamale eaters?" I just told him I come to like tamales fine. The men laugh, Ramуn smiles, but the look he gives Jenkin is tinged with speculative suspicion. Just then a patrol of three miners led by Alfredo Diaz enters scene from the hillslope. Alfredo reports to Ramуn. He is breathing hard
Two scabs got through on the other side of the hill. We chased the rest back.
Recognize them?
(shaking head)
Anglos. From out of town. But they're not miners -- I could tell that. They don't know zinc from Shinola.
Okay. Take five. Get yourself some coffee. As the three men of the patrol walk off to the coffee shack, one of the miners on the picket line calls out:

Hey, Ramуn, here comes the super ... EXT., WINDING ROAD. LONG SHOT: PICKETS' ANGLE. On the road from Zinc Town, across the trestle, we see a shiny new Cadillac crawling along the dusty road. It draw to a stop some distance away. CLOSE SHOT: CADILLAC. Superintendent Alexander sits at the wheel. Beside him is George Hartwell, a company representative from New York. Hartwell is impeccably dressed in a gabardine suit and Panama hat. He peers over Alexander's shoulder as the superintendent points out:
You can get the best view of the layout from here. That's their main picket line. They have another post on the back road, and roving patrols ...
showing the Sheriff's cars, the picket line, the unfenced hill, and the mountain of waste beyond it.
On company property? Why don't you have them thrown off?

But it's all company property, Mr. Hartwell -- the stores, the housing area, everything. Where do you throw them? And who does the throwing? Alexander nods, shifts the car into gear, and they move o EXT., ROAD. MEDIUM LONG SHOT: THE MOVING CADILLAC. It makes the bend, comes on up the hill and stops again near the Sheriff's cars, which are parked some thirty pac from the picket line. The Sheriff walks toward the Cadill
as the Sheriff comes up to Alexander's side of the car. T Sheriff has the appearance and speech of a New Mexican rancher, which he is. He touches his Stetson in a gesture of respect.
Mornin'.
How's it going?
Well, those new fellows you hired from out of town -- we brought 'em up here in a truck this morning, but they took one look at that picket line and turned tail.
(looking at pickets)
They don't look so rough to me.
(skeptically)
Well, Mr. Hartwell, they've got some pretty tough hombres, 'specially that picket captain there -- what's his name ... Ray, Raymond something-or-other ...

Oh yes. I know that one. He shifts into gear and drives off. The Sheriff touches h Stetson courteously. BACK TO PICKET LINE. The men are marching now, moving in a tight ellipse acros the road. Kalinsky hobbles along beside them on his crutches. Ramуn stands in the middle of the road, facing the picket line, his back to the approaching Cadillac. He lectures the men with mock severity.
Now why don't you let these gentlemen pass? Don't you know who's in that car?
(shouting)
It's the paymaster from Moscow -- with our gold.

No, no, it's the president of the company himself -- come all the way out here to make Jenkins general manager. So why you acting so mean? The miners grin as they march, one of them slapping Jenki on the back. INT., CADILLAC. TWO SHOT, THROUGH WINDSHIELD. The car is halted again, and the picket line can be seen b.g. Alexander is used to this treatment, but Hartwell is annoyed.
Aren't they going to let us pass?
Eventually. This is just a little ritual to impress us with their power.
Childish.
Well, they're like children in many ways. Sometimes you have to humor them, sometimes you have to spank them -- and sometimes you have to take their food away. (Points off scene.)
Here comes the one we were talking about. We see Ramуn leave the picket line and come toward the ca He is still sipping his coffee. Alexander chuckles.
He's quite a character. Claims his grandfather once owned the land where the mine is now. Both men laugh.
as Ramуn comes up. He leans down and peers inside.
(politely)
Want to go up to your office, Mr. Alexander?
(a half-smile)
Naturally. You think I parked here for a cup of coffee?
You're welcome to one.
No thanks.
(glancing at Hartwell)
The men would like to know who this gentleman is.
That's none of their affair.
(quickly)
That's all right -- it's no secret. My name's Hartwell. I'm from the company's Eastern office.
You mean Delaware?
No. New York.
(With mock awe)
New York? You're not the Company President by any chance?
(smiles faintly)
No ...
Too bad. The men've always wanted to get a look at the President. (eagerly)
But you've come out here to settle the strike?
(shrugging)
Well, if that's possible ...
It's possible. Just negotiate.
(coolly, to Alexander)
Are we talking to a union spokesman?

Not exactly. But I wish he were one. He knows more about mining than those pie-cards we've had to deal with. Hartwell is unprepared for Alexander's gambit -- but a ma falls suddenly over Ramуn's face. Alexander looks at Ramу continuing with all the sincerity he can muster.

I mean it. I know your work record. You were in line for foreman when this trouble started -- did you know that? You had a real future with this company, but you let those Reds stir you up. And now they'll sell you down the river. Why don't you wake up, Ray? (A pause)
That's your name, isn't it, Ray?
No. My name is Quintero. Mister Quintero. There is a moment's silence. Alexander compresses his lip chagrined at the rebuff.
Are you going to let us pass -- or do I have to call the Sheriff?

There's nothing stopping you. He steps back, indicating. THE ROAD, FROM THEIR ANGLE. The road is clear. The pickets are no longer marching, bu are lined up facing each other on both sides of the road. We hear the Cadillac accelerate. It plunges forward into scene, moves on past the pickets in a cloud of dust. Ramу comes into scene, moving toward the picket post. He bellows at the miners:

I was wrong! They don't want Jenkins for general manager -- they want me! The men laugh, re-form in groups on the road. EXT., COFFEE SHACK. MEDIUM SHOT. Ramуn, grinning, strolls over to Esperanza, who is standi in the doorway.
You shoulda heard that guy. What a line! I was up for foreman, he says. Fнjate! Esperanza smiles, then suddenly winces. Her hand goes to her midriff. Ramуn is alarmed.
What's the matter?
(smiles again)

It's nothing. Just a little catch ... She takes Estella by the hand and starts to walk down the road toward the Sheriff's cars. Ramуn escorts her. CAMERA PANS with them. Suddenly we hear from very far off a boy' voice calling:
Papa! Papa! Over here!
(looking hack)

Is that Luнs? What's he doing? Playing hookey again? THE WOODED HILL. LONG SHOT FROM THEIR ANGLE. In a thicket of juniper far up the slope we can make out two boys: Luнs and a comrade of the same age. They are waving their arms frantically. Ramуn walks into scene in f.g., cups his hands, bellows:
Luнs! Come down here!
(barely audible)
Papa! We seen 'em! Two scabs! Over there! CLOSER ANGLE: LUIS AND COMPANION.
(pointing)
They're hiding in the gully. Over there! BACK TO PICKET POST. The miners are trying to spot the scabs. They mill about restlessly, all talking at once:
Quй dijo? He's spotted two scabs ... Where? Over in the gully ... Come on, let's get 'em ...
(yelling)

Hold it, brothers! You -- Antonio -- Alfredo -- Cente -- you come with me. The rest stay on the line. The four men set off at a run on the road paralleling the railroad tracks. CAMERA HOLDS. Esperanza comes into scene in f.g. She calls in exasperation:
Luнs! Luнs! Come back here! Esperanza walks on, passing through the picket line.

as Luнs and his companion run diagonally down the slope. THE GULLY. LONG PANNING SHOT. Two figures scramble out of the gully. They run toward th railroad track, cross it and head for the uphill road to the mine.

running, fanning out, trying to cut off the strike-breake Cente makes for the tracks. Ramуn stays on the road. Antonio and Alfredo dart up the hill. GROUP SHOT: AT SHERIFF'S CARS. The deputies have roused themselves. The Sheriff smiles, gives them a sign. Four deputies climb into a sedan and drive off.
running. One of them, a blond Anglo, stops suddenly, then runs back the way he came. CAMERA FOLLOWS the other man. reaches the road leading up through the mountain of waste to the mine.

far behind the others, but coming on steadily, walking alone, as though in a trance. THE WINDING ROAD. HIGHER UP. Antonio emerges onto the road above the strike-breaker, cutting him off. THE STRIKE-BREAKER: SHOOTING TOWARD WASTE HEAP. He veers off the road, tries to evade his pursuers by climbing the steep pile of waste, but makes no headway in the powdery dust. Slipping, clawing, he creates a small avalanche, plunges back to the road below. THE ROAD, NEAR FOOT OF WASTE HEAP. The strike-breaker comes tumbling down, scrambles to his feet, runs back toward the tracks. CAMERA PANS with him. Cente suddenly appears, blocking his way. Then Ramуn appears, trapping the strike-breaker on the railroad trestle. The two miners advance slowly toward him. CLOSER ANGLE: AT TRESTLE. The strike-breaker stands there, panting, terrified. We are close enough now to recognize him. It is Sebastian Prieto.
who stops, stunned by this unexpected betrayal.
(panting)
Prieto ... Sebastian Prieto ... He comes on slowly toward Sebastian. There is murder in h eyes.
Ramуn ... listen for the love of God ...
You ... You ... I'd expect it of an Anglo, yes ... but you ...
Ramуn ... listen to me ... I'm in a        jam ... I had to get a job ...
You Judas ... blood-sucker ...
Ramуn -- listen my kids ...
(seizing his collar)
Tъ! Traidor a tu gente! Rompehuelga! Desgraciado!
My kids don't have enough to eat!
(shaking him)
You think my kids have enough to eat, you rat?
I know, it's wrong. Just let me go. I'll leave town ... just let me go.
(contemptuously)
You think I was going to work you over? I wouldn't dirty my hands with you ... He spits in the man's face and shoves him away. Sebastian trips on the railroad track and falls.

as seen from the road. The Sheriff's car plunges into scene in f.g., skids to a stop. The deputies pile out, run toward the trestle. In the distance we see Sebastian scramble to his feet, cross the railroad spur and retreat to the gully out of which he came. Ramуn stands watching him. The deputies are almost on him before he turns. One them seizes him by the arm. He appears to be protesting, but the men are out of ear-shot. Suddenly we see the flas of handcuffs snapped on Ramуn's right wrist. Ramуn, offering no resistance, holds up his left hand -- but a deputy spins him around with an arm lock and snaps Ramуn' wrists together behind his back. It all happens very quickly, and they lead him off.

standing in a group now, watching the arrest. Luнs starts to run to his father, but Antonio holds him back. MEDIUM SHOT: AT SHERIFF'S CAR. Ramуn is thrust roughly into the back seat of the car between two deputies. The other two get in front. The driver turns the car around, raising a great cloud of dus The car speeds off. CAMERA PANS with it, holds on Esperan watching at the side of the road. Suddenly ESPERANZA winces. Her hands go to her belly, and she bends slightly as though from a severe cramp. CLOSE SHOT: ESPERANZA. Her face contorted with pain, with the realization that h labor has begun. She looks around helplessly, calls:
Luнs! Luнs! The baby ...
listening, paralyzed, as we hear in Spanish:

The baby! Get the women! Quick! EXT., BACK ROAD. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. The Sheriff's car speeds toward us down the road, stops suddenly in a swirl of dust. This is an isolated area nea the mine; no observers can be seen. INT., BACK SEAT OF SHERIFF'S CAR. MED. CLOSE SHOT. Ramуn sits very straight, his wrists locked behind his ba The deputy on his left is a freckled-faced youth named Kimbrough. The deputy on his right is a pale, cavernous, slack-jawed man named Vance. Vance is slowly drawing on a pigskin glove. Ramуn glances at the glove. Then he looks out the window.
(his voice loud, tremulous)
Why do you stop?
(grins)
Wanna have a talk with you -- 'bout why you slugged that fellow back there.
That's a lie. I didn't-- The gloved hand comes up, swipes Ramуn across the mouth.
(softly)

Now you know that ain't no way to talk to a white man. EXT., ROAD, NEAR PICKET POST. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. We can see Mrs. Salazar and several other women running t meet Esperanza. A couple of pickets follow along. Mrs. Salazar shouts back at them in Spanish:

Go back and get a blanket, you idiots! So we can carry her! INT., SHERIFF'S CAR. MEDIUM FULL SHOT. Ramуn sits tense now, awaiting the next blow. A trickle o blood runs down his chin. The two deputies in front sit like wax dummies, paying no attention to what is going on in back.
Hey, Vance. You said this bull-fighter was full of pepper. He don't look so peppery now.
Oh, but he is. He's full of chile, this boy. He drives a gloved fist into Ramуn's belly. Ramуn gasps, his eyes bulge.
He likes it hot. His chiquita makes it good and hot for him -- don't she, Pancho? Vance strikes him in the abdomen again. Kimbrough snicker
The Sheriff is standing there with his other two deputies when Kalinsky hobbles up.
(breathlessly)
Sheriff ... we need a doctor -- quick. A lady's gonna have a baby ...
What d'ya take me for? An ambulance driver?
But there's a company doctor in town. We don't have a car. If you'd just go, get him ...

You kiddin'? Company doctor won't come to no picket line. Kalinsky clenches his fists, furious, helpless. Then he labors back toward the coffee shack. CAMERA PANS with him In the distance we see four men carrying Esperanza on a folded blanket. EXT., COFFEE SHACK. FULL SHOT. Mrs. Salazar is walking beside the improvised stretcher. She directs the men to enter the shack.
We can't get her home ... there isn't time. Take her inside ... INT., SHERIFF'S CAR. CLOSE SHOT. Ramуn is doubled up, his head between his legs. Vance pul him erect.
Hold your head up, Pancho. That ain't no way to sit.
(a mutter in Spanish)
I'll outlive you all, you lice.
(softly)
How's that? What's that Spic talk? He strikes Ramуn in the belly. Ramуn gives a choked cry. NOW THE INTERCUTTING BECOMES VERY RAPID. THE SHOTS ARE BRIEF FLASHES.
lying on a cot in the coffee shack, her face contorted wi pain. She gasps:
God forgive me ... wishing ... this child would never be born. BACK TO RAMУN. Kimbrough holds up Ramуn's head while Vance punches him methodically. Ramуn gasps in Spanish:
Mother of God ...have mercy ... CLOSE UP: ESPERANZA.
(in Spanish)
Have mercy on this child ... let this child live ...
biting his lip in agony.
(in Spanish)
Oh, my God ... Esperanza ... Esperanza ... Ramуn's voice carries over to: CLOSE UP: ESPERANZA.

Ramуn ... A contraction seizes her and she screams, her scream carrying over. CLOSE UP: RAMУN. Now the two images merge, and undulate, and blur, as with receding consciousness. And then darkness on the screen. We hear the feeble wail of a new-born infant.
Except for the altar lights in deep b.g. the church is in shadow. A group of five men and five women are silhouette at the altar rail, facing the priest. We cannot immediate identify them.

Ramуn was in the hospital for a week ... and then in the county jail for thirty days ... charged with assault and resisting arrest. But I made up my mind to postpone the christening till he could be there.

including not only the Quintero family but also Antonio a Luz, Teresa and Charley, Ruth and Frank, Sal and Consuelo Antonio holds the baby up to the priest, who makes the si of the cross. His lips move in prayer. Ramуn peers fondly at the baby over Antonio's shoulder.

... And so the baby was baptized the day Ramуn got out of jail. Antonio was his godfather, and Teresa Vidal his godmother. We christened him Juan. The priest sprinkles holy water over the infant's head.
The same men are seated around the parlor table, playing poker. From the phonograph we hear Mexican dance music. Consuelo bustles in with coffee for the men.

That night we had a double celebration: Juanito's christening, Ramуn's homecoming. INT., BEDROOM. FULL SHOT. The room is almost completely dark but we can make out th forms of six children sleeping crossways on the bed. The baby's crib is beside the bed.
And we put all the children to sleep in the bedroom, as usual. INT., KITCHEN. FULL SHOT. The five wives are gathered there, preparing sandwiches, talking.

And the ladies adjourned to the kitchen -- as usual. INT., PARLOR: AT POKER TABLE. The CAMERA ANGLE is that of a standing kibitzer. Ramуn is nearest the kitchen. Around him clockwise sit Antonio, Sa Charley and Frank. Sal is dealing the fifth card of a stu poker hand. The play is continuous and fast, a counterpoi to the more serious discussion.
And the men took over the parlor -- as usual. Her voice fades, and now we hear:
(throwing in matches)
Five thousand dollars.
Beats.
Raise you ten thousand.
You dog. All right, let's see them.
Aces, wired. (Scooping up pile of matches)
Come to papa. While Charley gathers the cards and shuffles, Frank turns Ramуn.
Hear those deputies slugged 'Cente.
Yeah. Lots of provocation lately. They figure if they can lock up the leadership on some phony riot charge, maybe they can bust the strike.
as Teresa reenters from the parlor. Ruth Barnes is tappin her foot restlessly to the radio music which continues ov scene.
Are we gonna let them play poker all night? I want to dance.
(roguishly)
With whose husband?
With any of them -- even my own.

If you dance with my husband, you'll have to put up with this ... She grabs Ruth and dances her around in a lascivious paro of Antonio's style. The women giggle. Esperanza's head turns at the sound of an infant's wail. INT., PARLOR: AT THE POKER TABLE. Frank is shuffling the cards. Esperanza is seen crossing to the bedroom in b.g.
(to Ramуn)
And another thing. Your attitude toward Anglos. If you're gonna be a leader ...
(cutting in)
What attitude?
You lump them all together -- Anglo workers and Anglo bosses.
(indicating Frank)
He's a guest in my house, isn't he?
Sure. But you want the truth? You're even suspicious of him.
Maybe. I think he's got a few things to learn about our people. There is a rather uneasy pause. Esperanza is seen re-crossing from bedroom to kitchen, the baby in her arms Frank continues shuffling.
Go on. Spill it.
(slowly)

Well, you're the organizer. You work out strike strategy -- and most of the time you're dead right. But when you figure everything the rank-and-file's to do down to the last detail, you don't give us anything to think about. You afraid we're too lazy to take initiative?
(defensively)
You know I don't think that.
Maybe not. But there's another thing ... like when you came in tonight -- (indicates picture)
I heard you ask your wife, "Who's that? His grandfather?" CLOSE SHOT: PORTRAIT OF JUБREZ.
That's Juбrez -- the father of Mexico. If I didn't know a picture of George Washington, you'd say I was an awful dumb Mexican. BACK TO GROUP.
(softening the blow)
I've never seen it fail. Try to give Ramуn a friendly criticism and he throws it right back in your face.
No. He's right. I've got a lot to learn.
Now we've got that settled, deal the cards. Frank deals. Sal grins at Frank.

If it makes you feel any better, he's got even less use for women. BACK TO KITCHEN. FULL SHOT. Esperanza sits on a stool near the stove, her back to camera and the other women, nursing the baby. Teresa and Consuelo are sampling the sandwiches they have made.
What are they talking about in there?
(from the doorway)
Discussing each other's weaknesses.
(mock surprise)
I didn't know they had any.
(looking o.s.)
Right now, Ramуn's on the receiving end.
Let's break up that game. BACK TO MEN AT POKER TABLE.
(earnestly to Ramуn)
If the women are shut off from life in the union ...
Bet your hand! Ruth enters scene with coffee for the men. The other wome save Esperanza, trail in behind her. Frank is so intent o his point that he ignores Ruth's presence.
We can't think of them just as housewives -- but as allies. And we've got to treat them as such.
(snorts)
Look who's talking! The Great White Father, and World's Champion of Women's Rights.
Aw, cut it out, Ruth.
(to Ramуn)

Me, I'm a camp follower -- following this organizer from one mining camp to another -- Montana, Colorado, Idaho. But did he ever think to organize the women? No. Wives don't count in the Anglo locals either. Ramуn laughs. Ruth turns back to him.
Not that I like the way you treat your wife. But when Doctor Barnes gives you his cure-all for female troubles, ask him if he's tried it at home.
(grinning)
Hey, Esperanza!
Esperanza's nursing the baby. A glow of eagerness brightens Ramуn's face. He flings dow the cards and goes out to the kitchen. The exasperated Antonio tosses his cards aside.
There goes the game.
Good. Consuelo, turn up the radio (To Antonio)

Come on, Papa, on your feet. Antonio gets up and begins to dance with his wife. We mar how accurate a parody his wife made of his style. Charley dances with Teresa. Ruth folds her arms, glaring at Frank INT., KITCHEN. CLOSE TWO SHOT. Ramуn stands beside his wife, looking over her shoulder a the suckling child. The CAMERA Ah.ANGLE is such that we cannot see Juanito.
(proudly)
Look at him ... Ramуn clenches his fists, tenses his forearms, grunts approvingly.
A fighter, huh?
He was born fighting. And born hungry.
Drink, drink, Juanito. You'll never have it so good.
He'll have it good. Some day. For a moment they say nothing, watching the baby. Then, with a sidelong worried glance:
What were they saying? About you? In there?
They say I am no good to you.
(shrugs)
You are no good to me -- in jail.
(musing)

I'd lie on my cot in the cell and I couldn't sleep with the bugs and the stink and the heat. And I'd say to myself, think of something nice. Something beautiful. And then I'd think of you. And my heart would pound against the cot for love of you. Esperanza is deeply moved, but she does not show him her face. Ramуn's face becomes tense with determination.
(half-whispering)
Not just Juanito. You'll have it good too, Esperanza. We're going to win this strike.
What makes you so sure?
(brooding)
Because if we lose, we lose more than a strike. We lose the union. And the men know this. And if we win, we win more than a few demands. We win... (groping for words)

... something bigger. Hope. Hope for our kids. Juanito can't grow strong on milk alone. His words are shattered by a loud knock at the front door Ramуn turns, listening. We hear the door open and voices indistinctly. CAMERA HOLDS On Ramуn and Esperanza.

This the Quintero place? What do you want? Got a court order ... You don't get in here without a warrant. We got the warrant too ... We don't want no trouble. All we want's the radio. Ramуn goes abruptly. CAMERA HOLDS on Esperanza, listening
We don't like to break in on you like this, but this fella owns the radio store, he got himself a repossession order on this radio here.
Don't touch it.
I don't want no trouble, Quintero. We got orders to repossess this machine. Esperanza rises swiftly, moves toward the parlor with the

I said ... don't touch it. INT., PARLOR. FULL SHOT. Everyone is standing. Several armed deputies stand around the radio console, ready to move it, but checked momentarily by Ramуn. Kimbrough's right hand is on the bu of his revolver. Esperanza enters scene. In one continuou movement, she hands the baby to Consuelo and blocks Ramуn clutching him, and speaking with a new-found fierceness.
Let them take it!
Over my dead body.
I don't want your dead body. I don't want you back in jail either.
But it's yours. I won't let them ...
(savagely, in Spanish)

Can't you see they want to start a fight so that they can lock you all up at one time? Slowly, Ramуn goes lax, and Esperanza relaxes her hold on him. The deputies pick up the heavy console, lug it towar the front door. The Quinteros' guests are glum and silent The deputies leave, closing the door behind them.
(bitterly)
What are you so sad about? He crosses to a shelf, picks up a dusty guitar and tosses to Sal.
Let's hear some real music for a change. Sal grins. He begins to improvise as we
In the distance we can see the tiny figures of the strike maintaining their vigil on the picket line. Behind them looms the lifeless head frame of the mine.

But the strike did not end. Ramуn was wrong. It went on and on, into the fourth month, the fifth, the sixth. The company still refused to negotiate. We couldn't buy food at the company store ... EXT., STORE WINDOW. MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT, DAY. A Mexican-American woman is looking at a display of canne foods in the window of a small town store. We see a hand place a small placard in the store window. It reads: NO CREDIT TO STRIKERS. CAMERA MOVES IN till the sign fills t screen, and we

They tried to turn people against us. They printed lies about us in their newspapers ... THE PICKET LINE. MEDIUM SHOT, DAY. A dozen or so pickets march counter-clockwise in a leisurely fashion. Antonio holds an unfolded newspaper which he appears to be reading to the others, but we hear

They tried to turn the Anglo millers against us. They said that all the Mexicans ought to be sent back where they came from. But the men said ... Esperanza's voice fades, and now we hear from the picket line:
(slapping newspaper)
How can I go back where I came from? The shack I was born in is buried under company property.
Why don't nobody ever tell the bosses to go back where they came from?
Wouldn't be no bosses in the state of New Mexico if they did.
(dreamily)
Brother! Live to see the day.
Jenkins ain't no boss. (Winking)
Mean we're gonna let people like Jenkins stay here?
You can't send him back to Oklahoma. It'd be inhumane.
(grinning)
But I was born in Texas.
(mock horror)
Oh no. That's even worse. They all start laughing, pummeling Jenkins as they march.

on a dirt road outside an adobe house. The car is piled high with the belongings of a Mexican-American family. Th mother and her children are in the car. The man is shakin hands with the neighbors in a sad goodbye.

And the seventh month came. By now the strike fund was nearly gone. A few families couldn't take it any longer. They packed up and moved away -- and where they went we do not know ... INT., UNION HALL. MEDIUM SHOT AT DESK, DAY. Sal and Charley are seated behind the desk. A number of miners stand opposite them. One by one, the miners count out money, hand it to the union officers. Ramуn stands nearby, watching.

And so it was decided by the union that hardship cases should seek work in other mines. And this was done. And the strikers who found jobs divided their pay with the union, so the rest of us might eat. INT., QUINTERO COTTAGE. MEDIUM SHOT, EVENING. The Quintero family is seated at the table. Their plates are empty. Esperanza picks up a bowl containing two spoonfuls of beans. She divides them among the children.

Ramуn was not a hardship case. Only three children to feed. No -- the Quintero family was not hungry all the time. Just most of the time. EXT., UNION HALL. FULL SHOT: A TRUCK, DAY. Two men stand in the back of the truck, handing down case of food to the miners. One of the men in the truck is a Negro. When Charley Vidal comes over, the Negro leans dow and shakes his hand warmly.

Even so, the mine owners might have starved us out were it not for the help we got from our International in Denver, and from the other locals. ... And we who thought no one outside our county knew of our troubles, or cared if they did know -- found we were wrong. INT., UNION HALL. CLOSE SHOT AT DESK, DAY. The desk is piled high with mail. Sal and Frank are openi it. We see dollar bills, loose change, checks.

Letters came. From our own people, the Spanish-speaking people of the Southwest ... and from far away -- Butte, Chicago, Birmingham, New York -- messages of solidarity and the crumpled dollar bills of working men.

head_text.subj: CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY TO DISCLOSE

text: two women at a mimeograph machine.
the union hall, disclosing other women at work -- cutting stencils, filing papers, sealing envelopes, etc. Several small children romp and climb over the benches.
But that was not all -- we women were helping. And not just as cooks and coffee makers. A few of the men made jokes about it, but the work had to be done -- so they let us stay.
standing behind a desk, sealing envelopes. The infant Juanito lies on an improvised pallet beside her, hemmed i by piles of leaflets. Estella is licking stamps.

No one knew how great a change it was, till the day of the crisis ... FULL SHOT: THE UNION HALL. The Sheriff, a U.S. Marshall, and several deputies appear suddenly in the entrance to the hall. They cross the room to Sal Ruiz' desk. The Sheriff is grinning broadly.

That was the day when the Sheriff and the Marshall came. The Sheriff was smiling -- so we knew he brought bad news. CLOSER ANGLE: GROUP AT TABLE. Sal takes the paper, reads it gravely. The Sheriff grins triumphantly and leaves, followed by his entourage.

The company had got a court injunction ordering the strikers to stop picketing. A Taft-Hartley injunction, they called it. It meant heavy fines and jail sentences for the strikers if they disobeyed. Sal rises slowly, re-reading the court order as Frank and Charley join him, reading over his shoulder. Their faces express worry, defeat.
A decision had to be made at once -- whether to obey the order, or not.

The hall is packed. The striking miners, as usual, occupy the center bloc of seats. But this time there are almost many women as men in the hall. They sit with their children in the rear or on benches against the side walls CAMERA HOLDS on Frank Barnes,standing at the front of the hall, addressing the miners.
(as Esperanza's voice fades)

If we obey the court, the strike will be lost ... the scabs would move in as soon as the pickets disappear. If we defy the court, the pickets will be arrested and the strike will be lost anyway. CLOSER ANGLE, FEATURING FRANK.

So there it is brothers. The bosses have us coming and going. I just want to say this -- no matter which way you decide, the International will back you up -- as it's always backed you up. This is a democratic union. The decision's up to you. REVERSE ANGLE, SHOOTING PAST FRANK AT MINERS. We hear a rumble of dissatisfaction as Frank sits down. There is no applause. Heads huddling, the miners grapple with the dilemma. Ramуn rises angrily.
If we give up now, if we obey this rotten Taft-Hartley law, we give up everything it's taken us fifty years to gain. There is only one answer: fight them! Fight them all!

How? They'll arrest us! We gain nothing. Their voices fade. Ramуn, still on his feet, turns on his critics, lashing them. Another miner rises, extending his arms in a gesture of helplessness. Over this we hear:

The men quarreled. They made brave speeches. It seemed that Brother Barnes was right -- the company had them coming and going. It seemed the strike was lost. FULL SHOT: THE UNION HALL. ANOTHER ANGLE. In near f.g. Chairman Ruiz is on his feet, pounding his gavel. In b.g. we can see Teresa Vidal waving for recognition. The chair recognizes her. Teresa has advance to the speakers table in f.g. Though obviously scared, sh is not as inarticulate or halting as Consuelo had been.
Brother Chairman, if you read the court injunction carefully you will see that it only prohibits striking miners from picketing. (A pause.)
We women are not striking miners. We will take over your picket line. We hear a stirring, then a raucous male laugh.

Don't laugh. We have a solution. You have none. Brother Quintero was right when he said we'll lose fifty years of gains if we lose this strike. Your wives and children too. But this we promise -- if the women take your places on the picket line, the strike will not be broken, and no scabs will take your jobs. There is silence in the hall now. Teresa starts to walk back to her seat when Sal's voice checks her.

If that's a motion ... only members of the union can make a motion. Sal glances at Charley Vidal, who sits beside him. Charle hesitates. Teresa glares at her husband. Charley takes a deep breath, yells:
I so move!
(from the floor)
Second!
(uneasy)
You've heard the motion. The floor is open for debate.
If we allow our women to help us, we'll be the joke of the whole labor movement!

Look, brother, our women are ours, our countrywomen! Why shouldn't they help us? THE HALL. ANOTHER ANGLE. We see miners with their heads together in heated argumen grimaces and gestures of disapproval, individual miners rising to address the chair. ANOTHER ANGLE, FEATURING LUZ MORALES. Eyes flashing, she addresses the men.
And Luz asked which was worse, to hide behind a woman's skirt, or go down on his knees before the boss? ANOTHER ANGLE, FEATURING GONZALES.
We haven't counted enough on our women. The bosses haven't counted on them at all. ANOTHER ANGLE, FEATURING CHARLEY VIDAL.

Will the bosses win now because we have no unity between the men and their wives and sisters? ANOTHER ANGLE, FEATURING A MINER AND HIS WIFE. A husky miner named Josй Sбnchez can be seen goading his wife to speak. The frightened woman finally obeys.
And Carlotta Sбnchez said she didn't think picketing was proper for ladies. It wasn't nice. Maybe even a sin. ANOTHER ANGLE, FEATURING GONZALES AND RAMУN.
I say give the sisters a chance ... Gonzales' voice fades, and Ramуn rises, glancing angrily Gonzales, and begins to speak.

And what will happen when the cops come, and beat our women up? Will we stand there? Watch them? No. We'll take over anyway, and we'll be right back where we are now. Only worse. Even more humiliated. Brothers, I beg you -- don't allow this. Ramуn sits down. There is scattered applause from the men Someone calls the question. REVERSE ANGLE, SHOOTING TOWARD CHAIRMAN.
(rapping his gavel)
All right. The question's been called. You brothers know what you're voting on -- that the sisters of the auxiliary take over the picket line. All those in favor will so signify ...
(a bellow)

Brother Chairman! A point of order! WIDER ANGLE, SHOOTING TOWARD TERESA AND ESPERANZA. Teresa nudges Esperanza. She rises shyly. It seems that Esperanza's stage fright will leave her mute -- but at la she finds her voice:

I don't know anything ... about these questions of parliament. But you men are voting on something the women are to do, or not to do. So I think it's only fair the women be allowed to vote -- especially if they have to do the job. We hear cries of approval from the women's section, intermingled with shouted objections from some men. GROUP SHOT: AT CHAIRMAN'S TABLE. Sal has to make a ruling, but he seems undecided. He glances at Charley. Charley winks, nods. He glances at Frank. Frank grins and nods. He clears his throat.
Brothers ... and sisters. It would be unconstitutional to permit women to vote at a union meeting. (Male applause.)
If there's no objection, we could adjourn this meeting ... There are cries of protest from men and women alike. He holds up his hand.
No, wait, wait ... and reconvene this meeting as a community mass meeting with every adult entitled to a vote!
I so move!
Second!
All those in favor will raise their hands. (Most of the hands are raised.)
Now those opposed ... (Only a few hands are raised.)
The ayes have it! Now, every adult is entitled to a vote!
Question! Question! Call the question!
(grinning)

Those in favor that the sisters take over the picket line will so signify by raising their hands. THE HALL. FULL PANNING SHOT FROM SAL'S ANGLE. An overwhelming majority of the women are voting for the plan. About a third of the men raise their hands -- but some of them lower their arms when nudged angrily by thei neighbors. Tellers move through the hall counting hands. CAMERA HOLDS on Ramуn, who is practically sitting on his hands. He frowns at:
her eyes averted, but her hand defiantly up. BACK TO CHAIRMAN. The tellers approach Sal, whisper the affirmative vote. H adds the totals, then pounds his gavel.

Okay. All those opposed? FULL PANNING SHOT: AS BEFORE. Most of the women sit with their fingers intertwined, as though in prayer. A few weaker sisters raise their hands uncertainly. Their neighbors nudge then. The hands come down again. CAMERA PANS to the men as the tellers count. We see a forest of raised hands. Some miners are frantically holding up both arms. BACK TO CHAIRMAN. MEDIUM SHOT. The tellers give Sal their figures. Sal's face is grave, reveals nothing. He rises, announces quietly:

The motion has carried -- a hundred and three to eighty-five. No applause. REVERSE ANGLE. FULL PANNING SHOT. A profound stillness has settled over the hall. The men turn in their places, looking at their womenfolk with dou apprehension, expectancy. CAMERA PANS to the women who line the side wall. They look at each other with a breathless wonder as the full import of their undertaking dawns on them.

This panorama should be as sweeping a vista as the first scene of the picket line. We get the sense of women streaming toward the picket post from four points of the compass. Some arrive in ancient cars, others walk by way the road or foot paths or the railroad tracks. There are so many women on the line that even though they march two abreast they overlap the road.

And so they came, the women ... they rose before dawn and they came, wives, daughters, grandmothers. They came from Zinc Town and the hills beyond, from other mining camps, ten, twenty, thirty miles away ... CLOSER VIEW: THE PICKET LINE. The women march in an orderly, determined fashion. There no gaiety. Teresa and Mrs. Salazar are in charge. They ar as bold and self-assured as two drill sergeants. Most of the women are dressed for the occasion -- wearing shirts, jeans and sneakers or saddle shoes.

By sun-up there were a hundred on the line. And they kept coming--women we had never seen before, women who had nothing to do with the strike. Somehow they heard about a women's picket line -- and they came. MEDIUM LONG SHOT: MINERS ON HILLSIDE. On the steep wooded slope above the picket post the varsi squats on its collective haunches. The men smoke, watchin the picket line with mingled awe and apprehension.

And the men came too. They looked unhappy. I think they were afraid. Afraid the women wouldn't stand fast -- or maybe afraid they would. THE HILLSIDE. ANOTHER ANGLE, HIGHER UP THE SLOPE. Several miners stand here with their families. They, too, look unhappy. Jenkins and his wife are among them.
But not all the women went to the picket post. Some were forbidden by their husbands. (A pause.)
I was one of these.

standing apart from the others, near a clump of juniper. Luнs stands beside his father, whose uneasy frown is directed at the picket line. Estella stands beside her mother, who holds the baby Juanito in her arms. Esperanza keeps gazing at the picket line off scene, never at Ramуn
It's not fair ... I should be there with them. After all, I'm the one who got the women the vote.
(stubbornly)
No.
But the motion passed. It's ... it's not democratic of you to ...
(interrupting)
The union don't run my house. (After a long pause.)
Those Anglo dames stirred you up to make fools of yourselves -- but you don't see any of them down there.
(squinting, peering)
Yes, I do. There's Ruth Barnes.
She's the organizer's, wife. She's got to be there.
NO, she wants to be there. (Looking off)
And there's Mrs. Kalinsky.
(pointing off scene)
There's Jenkins' wife. You don't see her on no picket line.
(quietly)
Anglo husbands can also be backward.
Can be what?
Backward. He glances quizzically at her. She keeps staring at: THE PICKET LINE FROM THEIR ANGLE.
(plaintively)
Can't I even put in an appearance?
In heaven's name, woman, with a baby in your arms? BACK TO FAMILY GROUP.

The baby likes to be walked. It helps him burp. Ramуn shakes his head. He looks off at: THE SHERIFF'S CONVOY. LONG SHOT. Some fifty paces beyond the picket line we can see two open trucks and two sheriff's cars. The trucks are loaded with men. EXT., SHERIFF'S CAR. MEDIUM SHOT. Superintendent Alexander, Chief Foreman Barton, the Sheri and the deputy Vance are standing beside the car. Alexander is in a petulant mood, but the Sheriff and Vanc seem amused by the situation. Three pretty Mexican-Americ girls pass by on their way to the picket line. Vance whistles at them. As they move out of the scene Vance calls:
Hey, girls! Wait a minute! Don't you wanta see my pistol?
Shut up. (As the Sheriff chuckles)
What's so amusing? They're flaunting a court order.
(grins)
Not so sure about that. Letter of the Law, you know. All the injunction says is no picketing by miners.
(furious)
Whose side are you on anyway?
Now don't get excited, Mr. Alexander. They'll scatter like a covey of quail.
(impatiently)
Well, let's get at it -- before another hundred dames show up.
(rouses himself, calls)
All right, boys. WIDER ANGLE: THE CONVOY. Drivers and deputies climb into the cab of each truck. Barton, Vance and two other deputies get into the lead ca Vance holds up his tear gas gun.
What about these?

Forget it. They'll scatter like quail. Barton starts the motor. He waves at the truck drivers an the other sheriff's car. They wave back. The convoy start up, gathering speed rapidly. FULL SHOT: MINERS ON THE HILLSLOPE. They spring to their feet, tense. FULL SHOT: THE PICKET LINE. The women stop marching, turn in unison to face the oncoming convoy.
hurtling toward the picket line. CLOSE SHOT: FACES OF MINERS. They groan involuntarily.
steady, unflinching.

horn blowing, speeding directly at them, looming bigger, closer. FULL SHOT: THE PICKET LINE. At the last split second, Barton jams on his brakes, and the car skids. The women have not moved. CLOSE SHOT: WOMEN AND CAR. The car skids into the picket line. A woman is swiped by the front fender, flung on to the road. FULL SHOT: THE PICKET LINE. We hear a collective gasp from the women. Then they screa Two women run to their injured sister. The others swarm around the car. The deputies are trying to get the doors open. The women begin to rock the car. Finally the deputi manage to get out. They flail the women with their fists, their gun stocks. But there are four women to each deputy and they cling to the men, grabbing at their weapons. MEDIUM SHOT: THE FIRST TRUCK. The Anglo scabs standing in the back of the truck react i fear and consternation. But they stay where they are. MEDIUM LONG SHOT: MINERS ON HILLSIDE. A group of them start coming down the hill. We can see Charley and Frank gesturing, trying to restrain them -- b the miners come on. BACK TO THE PICKET POST.
